A small correction which may have already been covered in the comments (I couldn't check them all!) during an ollie motion, your backfoot doesn't push down. your weight is biased in such a way that raising the front foot imbalances the weight so that the tail drops. almost all of the action in an ollie comes from the front foot, with the back foot needing to lift up when the snaps has hit the right place.

pushing the back foot down interestingly, is a common beginner mistake when learnig to ollie as this is generally what it looks like if you don't know what's happening!

Not true about the intermediate axis,  as long as the other mid axis provides corresponding torque, much like a vehicles rear axle, the plane will not rotate erratically, however, force can only be applied thru one rotation, after which more torque must be applied as the overall amount of torque can't be applied at original output of force. My pal, created his own skateboard in around. 1992.
Before he made, the skateboard in school. Construction, Design and Technology. I never saw a skateboard, with. Deck grip, all over the top of the board.
An upwards curve, on the nose and tail.
Before he created that skateboard. Boards were £10 had deck grip at the nose and tail. But, a smooth area in between.
There were, plastic, finger grips, on the sides, underneath. Also a plastic brake pad, on the rear. The tail was, bent but, the nose had no, curve in it.
Like Bart Simpson's skateboard! Rocket shaped.
Do you think he was an innovator? It must have been about '91. He created that skateboard in school. I don't know how he put the bends in it. But, I used to follow him around.
Watching him knock on his friends doors, he used to. Do skids. Dragging the tail, to slow down. We saw him once. By himself trying to jump over a 440 mm concrete block or something!
He is in a band now. But, I only see him online. We don't really correspond much these days.

The kickflip or heel flip. I could never do that! It's an jump with a 360 rotation of the board around the long axis.

I always rode my skateboard to physics in college. In our kinetics unit my professor randomly asks me if I can Ollie. I tell him, “of course I can Ollie, why?” He asks if I will come up on the lecturing stage and Ollie for the class. So I did. He then offers the class 3% extra credit on their final grade percentage if they can submit to him the correct equation and explanation why the Ollie was possible!

When he did the fakie-tre-flip it wasn't moving chaotically. His pivot point is on the corner of the board on the wave. It makes the board flip one full rotation on "both" the long and intermediate axis. It appears to happen sideways because hes neutralizing the chaotic affect of the median axis by kicking out the long-axis at the same time as the median axis. This lets him effectively predict when to land back on the board.

You made a mistake on how Rodney's fliptrick gets off the ground, it's not as simple as just stomping on the tail end. The reason he can control the board so well after the stomp is because his other foot grips the board, hence the grip tape, and with it, he motions his front foot upward, dragging the board up with it. You can see it in your video in your example. His other shoe is almost perpendicular to the board with as much rubber on grip tape as possible to get the best "pull" upward.

The same principles described here apply also when trying to hover a plane.  Imagine a plane as driving a car, but you want to hover you must rotate the axis to an imaginary axis, or for a better way of describing it, you want to drive the plane diagonally.  Once you hold full rudder ( this is to make the unstable aircraft more stable but rudder control is something else that must be carefully managed, too much or too little can upset the balance very quickly), you must manage the other 2 axis simultaneously along with managing your throttle to stay going in your intended direction of flight.  What Ive been doing in the flight sim in recent days is seeing the planes I fly as cars, with the shock absorbers front left on the left wing tip, front right on the nose or prop, and rear left shock on the rear elevator and the right rear shock on the right hand wingtip.  Its a little difficult at first to grasp this concept but once you get it its so easy.  Just learn to balance the plane and all the concepts are the same as this skateboard or anything else where you must smoothly balance and manage the x, y, and z axis.  The other thing that comes into play is inertia and momentum.  You need to know when exactly you can safely try something and this point is critical, you need to build up speed well in advance or else you will stall and fall or fail.  Thats what I have learned about it so far.  Im still learning as I go and each aircraft handles different because of the different shapes.  The main takeaway here is that the control of an axis of any type requires balance and knowledge of when you can safely release that build up speed for a trick or stunt - safety is critical.  The last part is practice, keep practicing and get the long hours in to know and understand and let it all sink in.

You got the explanation of the ollie wrong, but I don't blame you, very few people explain it properly. The popping of the board on the ground is NOT what gets you and the skateboard up in the air. It HELPS and helps a LOT, but is NOT necessary. And it is not just because the front of the board goes higher when its tilted like a seesaw. What gets you in the air ollieing is you simply JUMPING off your backfoot, propelling OFF of the force that is created by the lever counterweight of your bodyweight that is on the front end of the board.

The key is understanding you are really JUMPING off your tail BEFORE it hits the ground. And the only way that works is because you create the lever counterweight by having some of your bodyweight on the other side of the lever. You don't like jump off the ground at the instant it touches the ground, the board is already separate from your foot before it touches the ground and you are already going up and the (back of the) board is going down.

Simply friction from the front foot is then enough to literally drag the board up into the air after you've jumped yourself. Popping it and getting some recoil from the board certainly helps but is completely unnecessary.

What's even more of apparent physics defying feats is Danny MacAskill's trials bike riding.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z19zFlPah-o

Normally, a person who rides trials can't jump the height they do when they're riding a trials bike without the bike (i.e. they can't stand there and jump up to that height without a bike). In fact, with the bike, they would have to carry their own weight as well as the weight of the bike itself up to that level. Sure, there is a level of springiness in bike tires but that isn't enough to launch the weight of the person and bike, can it?

I deal with the intermediate-axis theorem in combat robotics. Whenever I design a spinner weapon I have to make it in such a way that it is never on its intermediate axis. In fact, you always want it rotating on the axis with the highest moment of inertia so you can get the biggest hits for the mass you have spinning.

Skateboards are springs. They "don't have springs in them" but the have a certain amount of spring in them due to flex. This is what we refer to as the "pop" in a board. While the majority of the lift in an ollie comes from leverage and friction, a small amount comes from pop.

From my perspective flipping and spinning every day objects is more of judging the instability of it and predicting where it stabilizes to "land," or in this case grab the object.
Physically an object can become unstable but our interaction is an outside entity altogether.
Thus we can influence things to become a visually appealing and entertaining form.
Kinda like how when a board gets too much velocity in the wrong direction it becomes very unstable.
Skaters predetermine their lift and sometimes even bend their knees upwards and inwards to compensate these variables as they get more intuitive/instinctive with a given trick.

I fall in that specific niche of being both a skater and physicist. I've always wanted to write a book about the physics of skateboarding. Not a lite book but something heavy like a text book.  The book of course would only appeal to those who with a deep comprehension of both skating and physics. Topics would include vector calculus, friction, tensor calculus, torque, centre of percussion, fluid dynamics, oscillatory motion. Other than sound and waves I can't think of an area of Newtonian mechanics that doesn't apply to skateboarding

The ollie is deception for 3 different reasons - 1 - It's always differentiated from just "jumping", but that doesn't mean you DON'T jump, you DO have to jump still, you're just not jumping off the ground, you're jumping off the normal force created by the lever action of your bodyweight across an axle. 2 - it's always taught with the pop, but it's possible to do it without any pop. You can get the ground off the ground completely without it smacking the ground by just dragging it up with friction and your feet and the lever action, but 3 - the friction with your feet also isn't totally necessary, it's possible to use only the lever action to get the board up and it could theoretically be done on a totally frictionless surface. The friction only helps and helps for guidance.

There actually is a spring mechanism in skateboards, the board itself. The flexibility and curvature of the wood plus the angled kicks make the board like a leaf spring in a car's suspension. The wood in the board is also layered (just like the leaf springs in a car.) Without this it would be harder to get the skateboard off the ground. It's probably only a small factor but it would still be a contributor. Great video, I love skateboarding & physics so this was right up in my niche.

How to lift a skate board off the ground is not just popping the tail to the ground, there is more physics to it. The tail is popped on the ground creating a counteracting force ( newton 3rd law) then to really lift it, you need to drag your feet on the top of the board that is making a nice angle with the ground, with this friction, a force lifts the board higher on the air, makes it leave the ground totally and make it level (parallel to the ground). It s this combination of reaction force and friction force that propel the board off the ground. You can actually see the motion of the front feet of the legendary Rodney Mullen making it happened.

The physics of an ollie is far more interesting. I learned to ollie by mashing hard on the nose after kicking it up, the momentum from which caused the tail to pop up maybe an inch or two, very unimpressive. It wasn't until I was much better that I learned I could get a much higher ollie by snapping the tail and getting out of the way to let the elasticity of the board do most of the work, a much more graceful maneuver and one that allowed me to achieve 18" ollies on flatland. But that is much harder because you are pounding the tail hard with your back foot then snapping your leg up immediately as high as you can. The dragging of the front foot is simply rotating the board from the nearly vertical position to level and has very little to do with the height achieved. When done correctly it looks like the board is literally glued to your shoes as you fly through the air. I doubt physics girl would understand any of this since the nuance probably escapes anyone who has never skated.

Interesting video thanks. A lot of it comes down to muscle memory and knowing/understanding the physics of rotation. I think it's the perfect match of athleticism and brains. It's one of those sports where size, weight and seniority in a sport mean little, well, within limits. An 8 year old and s 40 year old can be equal in ability when it comes to performing their art.

That Rodney is still able to knock tricks out consistently that most top skaters can't even do, is testament to both his raw athletic ability and his knowledge of physics. There is no-one that comes even close to creating as many tricks as Rodney, and there are some of his tricks that only 2 or 3 people have ever caught on film, despite skateboarding being a constant presence in the twenty plus years since he invented Primo, Casper and Darkslides, all of those also considered impossible until he found the key to the physics that made it work.

I'm grateful that you chose Rodney to work with, because he is so self effacing there have been times he has almost faded out of the scene entirely, to the point where few of the next generation had heard his name prior to the release of Tony Hawk's on PlayStation, and where he was doing a management job he detested and hardly getting to skate. Although he much prefers not being on camera, his name needs to always be covered with lights. If not for Rodney skating would have progressed differently. There'd have been no primo, dark or Casper in the Tony Hawk's game, bare minimum lol. He's an amazing man, a humbling skater and such a great teacher. Every minute of time Rodney spends teaching is a minute worth watching. Unbelievable skill, imagination, persistence, athleticism and an unquenchable thirst for knowledge of what boundaries can be pushed. A genius on a skateboard and not much less of one off it.

I've been a fan of Rodney since the Animal Chin days, where he had a small part doing some freestyle including a little pogo and a half cab flip of some sort, and the videos in the early nineties he did for Plan B and later Globe, as well as the Daewon Song trilogy of videos are all worth watching if you enjoy physics, whether or not you're a fan of skateboarding. To me riding a skateboard is one of the best demonstrable applications of physics. There's so much that can be taught using skateboarding for your examples, and it makes dry dusty physics accessable to those who wouldn't be interested. Showing that Rodney has a great understanding of physics will hopefully inspire all skaters to study physics to some degree to squeeze the most out of their performance. With it now being an Olympic sport as well as a counter culture, I'm sure physics will become an ever growing part of competition skating.

In terms of the Ollie. You're almost correct. Rodney stating that dragging your front foot is correct, pair that with the pop past the wheels/see-saw and you've got an Ollie. I feel angry after watching this, seeing the potential of what could have been. I don't know who this video is catered to, and I don't mean to dump on someone's work, but show this to some random skate fan before throwing it out there. Kids would have found it dissapointing, and so would more mature audiences. Insight about the intermediate axis theorem is missing, while praise and actual interest in the "art" that makes skateboarding is also faded. The legend Rodney was so well spoken and I have the feeling that he could have talked a lot more about a lot more tricks than just the impossible: you stopped him while he was already explaining the nollie impossible. Is that how you steer an interview in your desired direction? The overall feel is that this could have been directed on a trick by trick basis, and letting him develop a story and the mechanical details of how he performs most of them, only to add in editing commentary and actual useful equations and insight to the footage.

I don't know man... seeing you saying something like "I did not understand wtf you were saying" when he was using the basic analogy of pole vaulting to define the movement of his tricks made me realize that the thing that this video is lacking is actual interest and curiosity. That's important in Physics.

And I think there’s one detail that is often sort of forgotten in explanations. We’re so focused on the Board, that we forget the person. The first thing you need to do, I think, is to jump. And while your body is building up momentum and moving up, your kick foot needs to snap down quickly and lightly onto the tail, without shifting the weight over to the kick, and as the board snaps up follow up with pulling it up with your front foot and guiding it — all of this at the same time as your body is going up. If you start by snapping the kick down it’ll be too late to jump.

one thing, the board isnt necessarily pushed upwards, done in a certain angle, it will go straight up, but usualy what happens is rather that the initial kick (the hard hit on the ground) and because of the shape of the skateborad there , the board wants to spin around the (what i just learned was the) mid axis, if you look closely, you will see that that's the initial mouvement, right before it makes contact with an obstacle (his foot) that's moving upwards and that stops rotation around the long axis, then because of the grip tape, the foot is able to pull the skateboard higher, better quality of grip will transfers the momemtom from the rotation more efficiently. in RM's old videos, i could see him hit the skate really hard and then carry it upwards with his front foot which is how the board is lift off the ground, it's why an ollie is, physics wise, the sturdy base of skateboarding and it's the 1st trick almost everyone learns

As a skateboarder, it's  all trial and error. I would sit and nd try learning tricks for days, months, or even years. After a while you get used to the movement's and you understand how to control the board. Then you start landing the tricks. Once you land the trick repeatedly you can start combining the tricks you learned with other tricks. It took me 5 years to learn how to kickflip. It took about 10 to learn a fs boardslide. Combining the two is like a whole different trick. Not easy. After 15 years I can kickflip front boardslide on rails. That's just one combination. I know many more and like I said it's all about getting used to the board under your feet and also trial and error. Great video. Had one of my hero's in it. By stable I believe you mean there is no net torque acting on the board for the other axes while it spins on another. This is because the center of mass does not pass the edge of the base. But while the board spins on the horizontal axis, the vertical axis can easily have a net torque given the rotation about the horizontal axis isn’t started properly. Even the smallest torque could turn it. This is my take on the theorem

It's because objects will be inclined towards a stability over all axis, combined with how you'd never get a perfect push for a stable rotation, it comes down to skateboard shape and dimensions more than forces applied. With objects that are not symmetrical over all axis, you'll get the instability with the intermediate axis. The axis that allows for fastest spinning will generally always 'win' in this inclination towards stability.
With all the stuff we know from all the physics working on a whirlabout when it reaches stability, I was actually somewhat surprised the whole 'flip' in zero gravity was such a 'surprise'. It's also really not a random thing, it's obvious it is due imperfections of what looks like a stable rotation at decent speed, but really isn't perfectly stable at all. They should have done super slow-mo of that and you'll see what happens. Anyway, very fun stuff indeed.

Hey physics girl I have another skateboarding physics video idea for you. As a skateboarder for 20 years the most fascinating thing I have found about skateboarding is that if you do a trick with the precise amount of speed you virtually don’t feel the impact.
If I go very slow and Ollie down for stairs I can feel a good amount of impact… Sometimes even just four or five stairs cannot even hurt your muscles… However when I am skating full speed I can go off a 10 stare or more and the impact feels more like that of rolling off a curb. This obviously relates to plane landings verse helicopter landing. I’ve always wanted to talk with someone who knew physics on a deeper level, because I feel like math and physics can give us an idea of what the highest drop of impact a skateboarder can take would be… And how fast they would need to go in order for the impact off something extremely high to feel equal to that of say, a 10 stair going normal speed

wow this video made me subscribe so ty for bringing back my childhood. the only part that needed a little more info was the ollie/nollie. the push down isn't the only thing that gets you off of the ground. skateboarders use grip tape (basically  black sand glued to a piece of paper with a sticky side to apply it to the board). so it's a combination of both feet. there's the pop (which is the force you use to make one end of the board slap the ground) and the other foot comes up to let the energy of the pop raise the other side and then it slides forward (using the friction of the griptape and shoe) to raise the board off of the ground.

Science/Engineering/Physics videos need to make a shift away from adding tons of random equations in post filming to make the video seem 'techy.' Editors/Producers should make conscious choices to include relevant equations, which are useful to the audience/demonstration, and explain them if necessary. This is why I love skateboarding! There's so much physics involved as well as many life lessons one can learn from it. I feel like the reason I skate freestyle is because of Rodney Mullen and my love of science. I just find it so fun to see what the board can do depending on how you move it, how you pop it, how you position yourself on it and how you move with it. So many times I have found myself unable to land a trick only to take a step back and look at it through a more scientific lens and I immediately see exactly what I am doing wrong. It's trial an error, and even if some skaters don't see it on the surface they are scientists, testing different forces every time they try a new trick and when they finally master it they are basically mastering control over the forces they exude. It's exercise, fun and science all rolled into one and I'll never stop skating because of that. Also Rodney Mullen is my skate god and hero and because my style is based of his I've kinda gotten the nickname Rodney from my buddies at the skate plaza back home which i feel honored by, but no way will I ever be as amazing a skater as the legend himself.

Skateboard tricks operate by kinetic, potential or stored energy being released. In fact all movement of objects in space-time operate by this basic physical law.

Notice that the skateboarder bends or contracts (stores kinetic or potential energy) in their legs and arms every time they do a trick, very much like a rubber band or spring. As that energy is released it is transferred through their body down to their feet and through to the board. It's that physical energy that enables the board and the person to do their tricks, it's got nothing to do with the rotation of the skateboard itself. Rotation of the board it's speed etc is a function of the energy being released.

3:53 - DIANNA!!! Serious question... Does the Intermediate Axis Theorem apply to the Earth's core?

I believe most would say "NO" as the assumption is that they believe the Earth's mantle, outer core, and inner core are spherical. The Earth's actual shape is an oblate spheroid (i.e., it's flatter at the poles and wider at the equator). This leads me to believe that the super-dense inner core, an oblate spheroid, could move about it's intermediate axis and, therefore, obey the Intermediate Axis Theorem, which would explain the shifting of the Earth's magnetic poles. Your video, combined with the videos below (see references) inspired my question to you... so what are your thoughts!?

P.S. Love your webisodes and keep up the crossovers w/ Joe, Derek, Michael, and the rest of the eggheads out there!

References:

Well I'm not a physicist, but I have skated for a long time, and I can say that skateboards most certainly do have springness in a sense as a property - it's called pop and it's the ability of the deck to rebound off of hard surfaces. You even mention this when you say "then it hits the ground hard" - this is where the physical properties of the deck come into play. Over time when this property of the deck is lost, ollies become increasingly difficult to perform. The seesawing movement only amplifies the force with which the pop reacts and alone is not enough to lift the skateboard sufficiently off the ground. A simple way to confirm this is to make a deck out of a material that rather than being hard and "springy" is instead impact absorbent. This will make ollies with the skateboard almost impossible to perform. So yeah - maybe not springess in the sense of a spring that shoots the skateboard in the air, but definitely springness as the ability of the skate to bounce back when it hits hard surfaces.

you missed some parts of the ollie.

the board is a lever, using the wheel as a fulcrum (as you said). pushing hard on the tail or nose means that the largest mass of the skateboard is moving upwards while the lowest mass is moving down.
when the tail/nose hits the ground, the board's mass is still generally moving upwards, but the nose/tail can't go any further down, so the fulcrum rises off the ground, and eventually pulls the entire board up.
this is the bit that you missed: the board is then at an angle such that scraping the grip tape of the board (friction) helps to lift the board even higher. if you try to ollie on a board that has no grip tape, you will find it much more difficult.

So a monster flip is mathematically impossible?

Skateboards don't have springs, per se, but the board itself will spring about whatever fulcrum you are popping off.

Not everyone who skates understands this, but most skaters can feel it and identify when a board has lost its springiness. We have called it the board's "pop" for as long as I have been skating.

The bushings (pads within the trucks that help control steering) can also be used as another source of springiness, which is easier to use when actually spinning (since you typically need to push into a pocket of the board before jumping).

There is a ton more at play, but some people may find these extra details interesting. They are crucial!!

As a long time avid skateboarder who grew up wearing out VHS tapes of Mullen's skating, I can confidently say that he was and is the most important and innovative street skateboarder of all time. This is pretty long for youtube comment I know, but considering your topic of choice is Physics, that's kind of the name of the game when trying to explain these sorts of things so please bare with me because I'm one of those skateboarders who is into physics. I'm really sad to say, there are some really big/ incorrect leaps here throughout the video regarding the physics. First, the intermediate axis theorem doesn't really seem to apply because there's a force (the scooping foot) acting on the board through the entire rotation to create the spin. This isn't so much a flip in the same sense as a kickflip is because it's more like spinning a banana around your finger as opposed to freely flipping it in the air and then catching it upon completion of the flip. Notice how the tool in the space station is not acted upon by another force in this way while it spins. It is also much easier to see why this is not an intermediate axis flip when viewed in someone who hasn't been doing them for decades as it commonly results in an accidental 360 shuvit - a full long axis "flip" - when your foot doesn't act as that force (especially true when regular rather than nollie because as Rodney says, nollie "goes with the grain" ). A more accurate intermediate axis flip does exist and is called a Monster Flip which flips along the intermediate axis and does so free from the feet. This trick has been done plenty of times (on youtube), but it's not a very popular trick which is why you may have missed it. Also when he does the other trick that "starts like an impossible" (which is actually a casper 360 flip) he is flipping it in large part with the flick of his feet as opposed to it just happening like that up release. Lastly, when you pop your board there is more going on physically - part of why it seems to spring up and not just tip up like a seesaw is because you are transferring kinetic energy from your feet to the wood around the fulcrum and at the tip of the tail that is then released in the opposite direction as you snap the tail against the ground and lift your feet so they are no longer acting against the board. In a way it's more like a pogo stick than you let on because the tensile strength/ stiffness of the wood acting as a spring (think diving board). If you just step onto the tail fairly hard you'll notice that the board tends to bounce a bit before settling instead of just stopping, similar to holding a steel ruler down at the edge of a desk with a bit hanging off (to create the fulcrum) and making it spring to make sounds - the difference here being that not only is this happening but it's combining this with the pivot around the tip of the tail after it hits the ground along with the drag of your front foot. The front foot plays a much bigger part than what you let on too as it shifts the fulcrum towards the origin of the intermediate axis in the air and levels out the board around it. Side note: It's also possible to ollie without your tail even touching the ground because with a little practice you can generate enough upward movement just with the friction of your front foot as you drag it against the grip tape to level out.  PS: Research on skateboarding physics is totally the coolest and that was a little offensive to the skatenerds of the world (there's alot of us). :/

Why does sticky tack fail in different ways depending on how fast you pull it?  If you pull it really fast, you get a really quick and clean break.  If you pull it really slow, you get a really jagged and medium-size break.  If you pull it at a medium speed, it stretches and stretches and stretches until it finally gets too thin to support its own weight and snaps.

The math on Intermediate Axis is not THAT bad. It gets gnarly if you approach it from perspective of general stability analysis, but you really don't have to. All you have to do is understand axis tumbling, and that only involves some linear algebra. If matrix multiplication doesn't scare you, it's easy enough to see why precession axis stays near major and minor axes, and not near the intermediate axis. Still beyond the scope of this video, of course, but the implications of hard math seemed more discouraging than they needed to be.

I wonder what she'd make of the zero/monster flip. I'm surprised Rodney Mullen didn't mention it, too; I find it hard to believe he's never heard of it by now. It's an impossible without foot contact, spinning on the mid axis. Here's a video of Olli Fevang doing one: https://youtu.be/vtYhcalf40c

Hi Diana and company, I would love to hear your opinion on the pop-shuvit and the 3-shuv.

So the pop-shuvit I find to be rather elusive, because I can never get as much pop from it, as regular tricks like Ollie, Kick flip or 180...
I don't have the efficiency, as Rodney might say, to rotate the board and conserve upwards momentum.
But what I'm really interested in asking you folk, is about the 3-shuv:

Firstly, 3-shuv is the skater acronym/contraction for 360°pop-shuvit, which means you're spinning the board 1 full rotation around the perpendicular axis right.
I've watched plenty tutorials on how people do it, and some say that you need to guide the board with your foot all the way round, while others credit the catch as the important finally, do you or anyone on here have opinions about the 3-shuv and the effect of rotation around the perpendicular axis?

Thanks folks,

it isn't always unstable though, because I'm able to flip my phone like that, the way I call either Impossible or Monster flip, since and impossible is assisted and a monster flip is not. I'm sure you can tell more about the physics of it, because what really matters is how much force goes into it, how stable it is as it flips, and when it leaves your control. Often times if it leaves your control before that midpoint in the spin, it may go out of control, but if you guide it some of the way before letting it go, it will stay going down that path with no problem whatsoever.

Us skaters actually use the Long axis and mid axis to help guild our feet to figure out the right placement for our trick. I call it the T axis points. Because it's in the shape of a t. For example, for an Ollie you want your front foot to be in the middle of the Long axis point to have even pressure on your back foot so you get more "air time" while on a kickflip. I place my foot inbetween the Long and mid axis point to get the slight edge for the board to flick

There are a lot of myths surrounding how the basic ollie works.
One of the first things to realize, especially if you're trying to learn the trick, is that none of the skater's weight is on the board when it pops.
Imagine a skateboard with nobody on it. If you stomp down on the tail, it will bounce up in the air. That same thing happens in an ollie.
Using mostly their upper legs and some of their calves, the skater gives their body an upward velocity. Once their body mass is already heading up, they can kick the tail down to get the board to bounce up after them. From there, it's a matter of sucking their legs up, and guiding the board's ascent, mostly with the front foot.
Now it's also true that the front foot applies some leverage to level the board out once it's in the air, and even gain extra height, but that's not the main thing that gets the board off the ground. The board mostly just bounces.

The "foot drag" that a lot of skaters talk about has basically nothing to do with it. You don't pull the board up with you. You just jump, and then kick the board down to make it bounce up after you.

I've always been super curious about the physics involved in skateboarding.
The first time I tried a nollie, my brain kept saying: "You're moving forward and stomping on the nose of the board...you're going to go flying cause inertia gives a big NOPE to that."
...but I didn't go flying. The board didn't just stop while I kept moving...instead, I stayed on the board and kept rolling when I landed.

I'd love to hear the physics of a nollie! I mean, you're hitting the nose of the board while moving forward, but it still works. The pop somehow doesn't interfere with Newton's laws of inertia, which just boggles my mind.
Is it because the rest of the energy is transferring to the rest of the board after the pop?

The impossible became impossible for me to learn as a kid because the name suggested that it was impossible for mere mortals. This created a limiting belief within my ability to perform the trick and hence I never wired it. 20 years later I woke up to the profound impact limiting beliefs have upon our successes and although I have still not dialled the impossible, I am closer than ever! The difference is I now belief it is not an impossible trick set aside only for pro's but instead an appropriately named trick given the physical complexities of its movement. Great video! Thanks to both you and Rodney!

I've had a lot of theories about the physics of skateboard. The angle of spin or flip is sometimes different for e sry skater like for instance the 360 flip does not always spin horizontally in fact that's pretty uncommon. Depending on the size of the shoe/foot, weight/size of the board itself, weight of the skater, experience, scooping technique and foot placement all affect the angle of flip most of the times I've seen the 360 flip spin more at an angle of about 45 degrees as you can tell when the nose angles to about 45 degrees before completing the first 90 degrees of shuvit. Some people can flip the 360 flip at almost 90 degrees like am impossible see Mike mo's tre flip right before he front side boardslides big spins out on the bench. Interesting stuff

Fun fact: Rodney invented most all of the flip tricks we still do today.

Hello Diana, and Rodney,

Laughing you just answered a question that bedeviled me for years. To explain,, I used to do a lot of very free style skiing. I could do a single axel,, and even a 540,,, but double axel or triple axel,, my shoulders were so bruised and so often dislocated,,,, I tried for years, succeeded maybe one time. The normal result on an attempt was the vertical axis spin,, inverted and my shoulder would auger into the slope,,, quite painfully. The one winter by January I had several shoulder bruises and two dislocations,,,, and I kept trying.

Rodney, you just explained it. I was pulling my hands in too quickly,, and the opposition to that,, full length skis do not 'pull in'. And over I would go. I finally did learn,,,, not to do it anymore. At least 35 years later,, nice to know why.

Slight correction, it is not actually the normal force that pushes the board up. You create torque on the board around the pivot point (the wheel) which then, because the skateboard can be seen as a solid object, moves the part of the skateboard on the the other side of the pivot up. This creates an angular momentum around the center of mass (com) of the board but also gives the com itself upward momentum. The upward momentum you create by pressing down past a pivot point that is not the com is what makes you keep going up. The only thing the normal force does is counteract that angular momentum you also created besides the upward momentum you really wanted. Bit nit picky I'm sorry but physics is a science :)

+Physics Girl  There's an intuitive explanation that I've found for the intermediate axis theorem.  Rotating along the long axis has a small moment of inertia but its instability is in the short axis of rotation.  The short axis has a large moment of inertia, but instability in the long axis.  Although the long axis has a small moment of inertia, it has a small distance to cause a torque so it's unlikely to cause significant rotation.  The middle axis, however, has a medium moment of inertia with significant distance to cause the instability torque.  That's part of the reason (I think) that the axis is so unstable.

There actually is a trick that spins about the intermediate axis without using the foot to guide it, it is possible, I can do it myself. We call it a "monster flip" or "zero flip" (a great examble by Olli Fevang: /watch?v=vtYhcalf40c) and I'm not exactly sure why it works.

[rambling about why it works:]
It's either the same as throwing your phone that way and just getting the rotation precisely enough for it to not flip into the other rotational modes or (which I'm hoping :D) that rotation gets some sort of extra stability through either the spinning wheels or because of pressure on the board. Popping that trick requires quite some bending of the deck, so perhaps the "moving back into the original shape" stabilizes the trick a bit more, counteracting the metastability a bit.

I attended classical mechanics lectures in the first semesters, but calculating that using Hamilton equations or similar would be insane to do, especially considering the four wheels plus the bending of the wood.

I'm not entirely sure that the board rotates about its intermediate axis.  It seems likely that the board is rotating about Rodney's foot (which is itself moving in three dimensions).  Rotation around a non-central point is a more stable movement, or tetherball wouldn't be possible (and planets wouldn't stay in orbit).  The trick to 'the impossible' would then be making the board stick to your foot, which isn't "impossible", just very difficult -- kind of like doing a card trick while skateboarding.  Mind you, this is coming from someone who can't skateboard.

Flipping a tennis racquet?!?! LOL, that's so funny to me because I used to play a LOT of tennis. One day between rallies, I started flipping the racquet and noticed that it always made an extra half twist that I did not intend for it to make. I couldn't figure out why it did that (this was before the internet was a thing), so I practiced flipping it in order to make it not twist. Eventually, I got good enough that I could do it. Since I could now flip it without the twist (with great concentration), I assumed the twist had resulted from some unwanted muscle action on my part. Now I know what was really happening! :)

Don't listen to this abstract fake understanding of what's happening. This is not magic. Watch on .25X speed and you can see what's going on, without any theorem or using ignorant words like "spontaneous". They can call it "instability", but really it's the conservation of momentum. When you flip the phone, the slightest unequal amount of force conveyed by one of your hands or whatever flipping method you're using, will be retained in the movement of the phone/skateboard. Also, your phone and even a skateboard aren't symmetrically dense (But the asymmetry in the flipping method is by far the biggest factor, probably in both cases). The phone more than the skateboard has parts in one section that it doesn't have in other parts. The phone weighs more/less in different places on the phone. So imagine that you somehow use your hands to flip the phone using exactly the same amount of force. Undetected by you, the phone's interior is actually a landscape of diverse components that each have different mass and different/chaotic placement of that mass. The phone is going to flip. Given the inequality of your flipping technique, AND the inequality of the weight of the phone, it would be amazing to flip it without it doing something interesting. But notice that there's no special physics going on. 3:52 When the part in space is spinning, it is WOBBLING. It too flips because of these two factors. And also the spinning becomes kind of continuous again because of a gyroscopic effect. And also, it is not "spontaneously" flipping, but actually flipping with somewhat predictable regularity. It flips when the wobble somewhat overcomes the spinning and quickly wobbles to the other side, which then lets the main piece keep spinning around (This wobble might even be slowing down the spinning. I'd like to see how the thing is moving in 5 minutes). But notice also that it drifts away, further indicating that the movement is not simple like one straight line might represent. There are many directions of force, and when you acknowledge those different, unintended directions of force, you'll understand this. What's even cooler, is that the motion of wobbling from one side to the other creates another force! That force might be the main reason for the drift.

Though I still don't get how he gets off the ground.

I'm 41 and have been a giant Mullen fan since I was a little kid growing up around the industry (he's a really nice guy, as you found out). Lots of people these days have no idea that he invented pretty much all of the fundamental movements that the complex tricks are based off of. He didn't set out to be the keystone in a multi billion dollar industry, he just did Rodney things in the Rodney way and it happened organically. That's how the best things form.

As an aside, why not just one, but several mentions where you are almost embarrassed to be making a skateboarding video? You've done tons of videos of really obscure phenomena, and so does everyone else so it feels strange you'd choose this one particular topic to get that way about, especially when dealing with the absolute top of the food chain in the sport so it's not like you just mailed in something boring at your local parking lot one morning while killing time.
